title: Will Egypt’s GDP growth rate for their 2016/2017 fiscal year equal or exceed 5%?
preds:
My answer is no.
Egypt GDP	           Last	Q2/17	Q3/17	Q4/17	Q1/18	2020
GDP Growth Rate  3.4	        3.8	        3.6	       4	        3.7	            4.9
Rates go up growth goes down? http://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-cenbank-rates-idUSKBN18H113

According to official statistics, GDP growth remained below 4 percent in the first three quarters of the current fiscal year, which will end on June 30. Growth was calculated at 3.4 percent in the first quarter of 2016/2017, compared with 5.1 percent the previous year, and it increased to 3.8 percent in the second quarter, compared to 4 percent the previous year. It then climbed to 3.9 percent in the third quarter, compared with 3.6 percent in the last fiscal year.
They have made some extremely modest and probably ineffectual reforms of late, but neither big enough nor dramatic enough to affect this year's numbers.

Going from 1 to zero because, well, the country isn't getting better and Sisi is now working to eliminate any semblance of the rule of law by taking over the judiciary. That's a great way to hurt business confidence and scare off foreign investors.

Why all the 0-%-forecasts?
The difference btw 3% growth and 5% is not that big. Look at the history of the Egyptian economy since 1966. It is not a roller coaster, but has high variability. Sure most forecasts say 3%, but random stuff can hike it up. My forecast is not great, I base it on basically nothing, but it is certainly higher than 1%, so I am going to improve my score compared to the average guesser of today. The question we should ask ourselves is "how often does a genuinely crappy economy with terrible governance increace by more than 5%, after a few years of poor growth". Certainly more often than 0% of years. Another thing that might hike it up is fraud. The chance the government or something fudges the numbers should be at least 1%.
Egypt is doing surprisingly well when it comes to their IMF loan yet it is still plagued by institutional decay which often works against economic growth.
State of emergency will likely harm the economy. Reaffirming forecast.

The economy is expected to lose steam in FY 2017. While the government is betting on fiscal consolidation and enhanced reform implementation to improve Egypt’s long-term prospects, this will weigh on both household consumption and capital spending in the near term. Analysts expect GDP to expand 3.0% in FY 2017, which is down 0.4 percentage points from last month’s forecast. For FY 2018, the panel sees growth accelerating to 3.8%.
http://www.focus-economics.com/countries/egypt
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Kept this at 1 for a while to allow for the possibility that the government of Egypt would fudge the figures.  I have come to lack confidence in their ability even to do that.

The economy is growing well enough (2-4% annually) since the Arab Spring. However, that may be the plateau of Egypt's growth absent the sort of liberalizing reforms organizations like the IMF are always demanding and that Sisi does not seem interested in. Makes me glad the question asks about 5% and not 4%, that would be a much more challenging/interesting question to answer.

economic growth to 3.4% during Q1 of FY 2016/17 
http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2017/02/02/613786/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Economics is not my strong suit, but I know that having three presidents in six years can’t be good for business. Egypt hasn’t broken 5% since before the Arab Spring, and military coups are rarely good for an economy. No way.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

He emphasised that, in the current economic reality, achieving a 5% growth in GDP is not possible.
http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2016/12/28/egypts-economic-targets-line-economic-reality/ 2.Egypt's economic growth rate up to 3.4 pct in Q1 of 2016/17
http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/3/12/254759/Business/Economy/Egypts-economic-growth-rate-up-to--pct-in-Q-of--.aspx 5% doesn't look attainable with those dismal figures.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
5% only because they're starting from such a low point.

Although parts of the economy are seen sings of been stabilized, in Egypt things have the bad omen of changing fast.
I think that the running numbers will stay on track at the range of 4.5% (with a spread of 4.4 to 4.6) is more in tune and provable than above 5%; in the present situation is still a good number.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
I foresee a number of black swans flying across the mideast in 2017. Countries will be beset by unintended and intended consequences.
Business tanks during a military coup.

No, no, and no.  Link has been around for a while, but "on the money' so no  need for mind-bending analytics...
http://egyptianstreets.com/2016/04/13/egypts-economic-growth-to-slow-in-2016-recover-in-2017-imf-forecast/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

While the loan may help Egypt has so many problems that it probably will not be enough to resolve this question as a yes. The austerity measures could also lead to mass unrest which would discourage foreign investment and threaten the present government.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Growth will be evident but likely to be less than 5% given regional issues persist.
According to the WEO the growth to GDP for Egypt is 3.8% and 4.0% for 2016 and 2017 respectively
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Too much needs to change for this to happen.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the Economist the Q1 annualised growth was 6.7% but the forecast for 2016 is 3%. 3.8% based on the latest IMF release.

Facts are:
1.Tourist inflows have been weak, people are scared to travel to the North Africa and the Middle East for obvious reasons.
2.Industrial production growth in 2015 blew most of the other countries out of the water, but how much did government subsidies help in the process?
3. Inflation, unemployment, weaker currency, as well as a growing deficit are solid enough indicators to make you suspicious of achieving a GDP growth of >=5%
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Egypt's GDP growth rate since 2011 gov change has been well below 5% overall but several quarters have been above 4%, one reaching 6.8% growth.  Egypt's GDP growth was routinely over 5% in the decade before the change in gov.  It seems unlikely to hit 5% in 2017 but such a change in growth rate would be in-line with Egypt's economic history.
Egypt is surrounded by conflict and dependent on peace in the region to thrive and rebuild their economy.

All the estimates that I've seen are for less than 5% growth, including this recent estimate by Moody's of 3.0%: http://www.econotimes.com/Moodys-Expected-gradual-economic-recovery-in-Egypt-will-drive-profit-growth-for-insurers-318941
Bad government policies in a volatile economy hampered by a slump in one of its pillars - tourist industry.

"Growth remains under pressure in Egypt. The tourism sector has slumped further, foreign exchange shortages continue 
and electricity constraints are affecting manufacturers. Austerity measures are necessary to reduce the high fiscal 
deficit. We expect GDP growth of 3% in 2016 and 3.5% in 2017. "
http://www.icaew.com/-/media/corporate/files/technical/economy/economic-insight/middle-east/me-q3-2016-web.ashx
A poorly performing economy in a time of low-growth and in a volatile region. Not an encouraging combination.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

From Trading Economics (.com), GDP Growth Rate Forecast 
                 Q4/16	Q1/17	Q2/17	Q3/17	2020
EGYPT      3.80        3.4          3.6          3.9           4.9

Economy in "doldrums" source link http://www.focus-economics.com/countries/egypt World Bank revised downward to 3.8% in January source link http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/3/12/180351/Business/Economy/World-Bank-cuts-Egypts-predicted--growth-rate.aspx Trading Economics forecasting under 5% source link http://www.tradingeconomics.com/egypt/gdp-growth/forecast Draw your own conclusion as to why Egypt can't master the possibilities;)
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
They would have to increase trade, the world is weak, I don't see this happening.
Hasn't hit that target in years. Plus recession

Tourism is down; there is a foreign currency crunch; there are strict capital controls; and the military has sprawling business interests and uses its influence to strong arm medium sized businesses to take up contracts with unattractive terms and it is frequently awarded very attractive construction contracts from the government and is often given a piece of every pie. The IMF loan will probably help but given how slowly the Egyptian government makes significant reforms, it is unlikely that any significant reforms that will help businesses and create a more competitive free market environment will come into effect in the following year(s). A return to pre-revolution GDP figures is incredibly unlikely. 3-4% growth would be far more likely, especially in the 3.0-3.2% range.
Egypt depends upon tourists-currently at zilch.
Nothing in their economy will change for the good.  Oil producers are struggling as well.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

anchor
======
- Worldbank estimates 4.2% GDP growth
- IMF GDP growth outlook <5% until 2020
- since 2000, 5% was only exceeded in 5 years. 
+ 6.7% growth in Q1:2016
- EIU says <4%
==> p=0.26 further information
====================
- less inflow of FDI/aid from other Arab states (partially due to oil prices) [-4 probability points]
+ IMF deal in sight, but only with pre-conditions (sign that IMF's willingness is limited); "But Chris Jarvis, head of the IMF delegation, told the Financial Times that the IMF funding was contingent on Egypt securing between $5bn and $6bn in additional loans from bilateral partners" [+1ppts]
- Sisi is authoritarian. "Mr Sisi has proved more repressive than Hosni Mubarak, who was toppled in the Arab spring; and he is as incompetent as Muhammad Morsi, the elected Islamist president, whom Mr Sisi deposed." (Economist) [-3.5ppts]
- political elite is prone to large, wasteful projects (Suez canal, new capital)
- tourism likely to pick up only slowly, danger of attacks and political instability
- political instability due to high youth unemployment (40%) [-1ppts]
- high budget deficit (around 10% of GDP) may force Egypt to austerity (negative impact on GDP growth) [-3ppts]
- Egypt's unwillingness to devaluate the Egyptian pound, high inflation /despite/ attempts to stabilise pound
- corruption & too large public sector [-1ppts]
- number of arrivals 4 million below peak (in 2010), 9.6 million in 2014. high potential. 
- EU and global growth subdued. [-3ppts]
- VAT increase, taking effect in Oct 2016, may lead to a decrease in consumption
+ pop growth 2+% [0ppts]
+ unemployment forecasted to go down [+1ppts] conclusion: baseline estimates of IMF/Worldbank below 5% real GDP growth, but many downside risks (political instability) and need for austerity & structural reform (which would likely lead to short-term recession). At the same time, no sign of reform willingness in the government.  plus weighting with my forecasting partner.  p=13.4%.
Think there is 0% chance but at least a 7% chance they will lie in the published figures
Looks like growth will be no higher than 4.5%, but this is a long-dated question.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

In Egypt unemployment remains high notably among the youth. The fiscal deficit is still large and domestic public debt high. Reserves are about three months of imports, and foreign exchange is in short supply.
The economic outlook is clouded by the acute dollar crunch, weak fiscal accounts and political instability. Downside risks to Egypt’s GDP growth increased with the UK’s Brexit vote as the two countries have relevant trade and investment connections. Our panelists expect GDP to have expanded 3.1% in FY 2016 and forecast growth of 3.7% in FY 2017.
-----------------
@kmcochran
another good question could be if Egypt will receive from the IMF a three-year conditional credit line.
At the moment difficult to see the criteria or the IMF loan being met. I will probably have to review this question a few times in the coming year.
They haven't reached that kind of result for a long time.

According to the website "market realist" (http://marketrealist.com/2015/01/2-factors-drive-real-gdp-growth/) the two factors that have the biggest impact on the GDP growth rate are population growth and GDP worker (I assume this is per capita), and thirdly employment-to-population ratio (ie. employment rate?). As I dont know that much about economics, I am assuming this at face value. The population growth in Egypt will be at 2.05% for 2016. That is a reduction from 2016, but still higher than the 2000s (when the growth was higher than it is today), http://www.worldometers.info/world-population/egypt-population/. The GDP/capita in Egypt increased from 2014 to 2015, after 3 years of decline http://www.tradingeconomics.com/egypt/gdp-per-capita. So these two factors are on the rise. On the third, apparently minor factor, of unemployment rate of Egypt went up from circa 8% in 2011 to 12% during that year http://www.tradingeconomics.com/egypt/unemployment-rate. This peaked in 2014, the year following the coup, and has steadily been slowly declining. So two out of three factors are good, and even better than pre revolution levels. In 2014 the rate was almost at 5%, but has since gone down, so with this I would say it is around 30%. However, clearly political events like the 2011 revolution affect the GDP growth rate. The coup in 2013 also seems to correlate with some of the negative growth associated with above mentioned factors. Furthermore, the security situation remains unstable with attacks by ISIS against civilians and military targets. The continued marginalisation of moderate opposition like the Brotherhood will only contribute to this, so it is not likely to improve. This leads me to believe it is less than 50%, more towrads the mid to high teens.
(I do not think the development of the tourism industry in Egypt will have a big effect on the outcome, as it did not and does not contribute to more than circa 10% of the economy of Egypt (accoridng to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tourism_in_Egypt))

Furthermore, the security situation remains unstable with attacks by ISIS against civilians and military targets. The continued marginalisation of moderate opposition like the Brotherhood will only contribute to this, so it is not likely to improve. This leads me to believe it is less than 50%, more towrads the mid to lower 20s (I do not think the development of the tourism industry in Egypt will have a big effect on the outcome, as it did not and does not contribute to more than circa 10% of the economy of Egypt (accoridng to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tourism_in_Egypt))

I suspect that with the uncertainty of Egypt's future it makes it doubtful they will reach a 5% growth rate on GDP. Their inflation rate is over 9%, the $12 Billion loan from the IMF may not help either, and their international  situation doesn't look good.
A more steady gdp in 2017 but not where the forecast says,

Hard to see a path for this to happen just now.  The current guy, whose name is not Abdel the Fat Sissy although it should be, has made hash out of the economy and the government and civil society and just about everything else in Egypt.  They might hit 4%, but if I had any money it would be on 3% or even a bit less.
Lack of stability.  Giving money to a sputtering economy is like pushing a rope.

" Mr Sisi desperately needs the cash. His government faces large budget and current-account deficits (almost 12% and 7% of GDP, respectively), as Egypt’s foreign reserves run perilously low. An overvalued currency, double-digit inflation and a jobless rate of 12% complete the dismal picture. Potential investors are staying away. "
http://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21703393-egypt-has-squandered-billions-dollars-aid-more-way-it Consensus forecasts are below 5% gdp growth rate. "Economic growth will therefore average below recent peaks at 3.2% annually in 2016-20."
http://country.eiu.com/egypt WB predicts 4.2% 
http://pubdocs.worldbank.org/en/38111460208801133/Egypt-MEM.pdf IMF predicts 4.3%
"Egypt’s GDP growth is forecasted at 3.3 percent in 2016, representing a drop from 4.2 percent the previous year. The country’s GDP is expected to rebound in 2017, reaching a growth of 4.3 percent."
http://egyptianstreets.com/2016/04/13/egypts-economic-growth-to-slow-in-2016-recover-in-2017-imf-forecast/ It is unlikely everyone got their forecast wrong. Egypt in terrible financial situation, and 2017 has no reason to be better and could be worse.

Every thing that can stall an economy is happening in Egypt.  Falling foreign reserves.  Currency controls.  Unrest and unemployment.  Foreign Godfathers across the Red Sea with their own problems and thereby restricting the amount of help they can provide will also be a missing helping hand.   The question is not if the economy will hit or pass the 5% mark but will the government report it happening even if it does not hit that number.
Not a chance. Too many systemic flaws to achieve that level of growth.
